para.p:
Let
= H
{
∈ τ C
:
>
⁢ Im τ
0
}
. Define
: C
→ H C
by

Math.text: formulae@(C * tau = 2 * ((sum _ (n = - infinity)) ^ infinity)@(1 / (e ^ (pi * i * n * tau) + q ^ (- pi * i * n * tau))) = ((sum _ (n = - infinity)) ^ infinity)@(secant@(pi * n * tau)), tau element-of H)

para.p:
We take as granted that
C
is holomorphic on
H
.

First we calculate the Fourier transform of
↦ x
⁢ sech π x
. 1 footnote 1 1 footnote 1 Elias M. Stein and Rami Shakarchi, Complex Analysis, p. 81, Example 3.

Math.text: ((integral _ (- infinity)) ^ infinity)@(e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * xi * x) * sech * pi * x * differential-d@(x)) = sech * pi * xi
f * z = e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * z * xi) / hyperbolic-cosine@(pi * z)

para.p:
The poles of
f
are those
z
at which
=
cosh
⁢ π z
0
, thus
= z
+
⁢ n i
i 2
,
∈ n Z
. Taking
γ R
to be the contour going from
- R
to
R
, from
R
to
+ R
⁢ 2 i
, from
+ R
⁢ 2 i
to
+
- R
⁢ 2 i
, and from
+
- R
⁢ 2 i
to
- R
, the poles of
f
inside
γ R
are
i 2
and
⁢ 3 i
2
. Because
=
(
cosh
⁢ π z
)
′
⁢ π
sinh
⁢ π z
, we work out

Math.text: Res _ (z = i / 2) * f * z = e ^ (- ((2 * pi * i) cdot (i / 2)) * xi) / (pi * hyperbolic-sine@(pi * (i / 2))) = e ^ (pi * xi) / (pi * i * sine@(pi / 2)) = e ^ (pi * xi) / (pi * i)

Res _ (z = (3 * i) / 2) * f * z = e ^ (- ((2 * pi * i) cdot ((3 * i) / 2)) * xi) / (pi * hyperbolic-sine@(pi * ((3 * i) / 2))) = e ^ (3 * pi * xi) / (pi * i * sine@((3 * pi) / 2)) = e ^ (3 * pi * xi) / (- pi * i)

para.p:
We bound the integrals on the vertical sides as follows. For
= z
+
- R
⁢ i y
,

Math.text: absolute-value@(hyperbolic-cosine@(pi * z)) = absolute-value@(e ^ (pi * z) + e ^ (- pi * z)) / 2 >= absolute-value@(absolute-value@(e ^ (pi * z)) - absolute-value@(e ^ (- pi * z))) / 2 = absolute-value@(e ^ (- R * pi) - e ^ (R * pi)) / 2 = (e ^ (R * pi) - e ^ (- R * pi)) / 2
absolute-value@(e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * z * xi)) = e ^ (2 * pi * y * xi) = e ^ (4 * pi * xi)

absolute-value@(hyperbolic-cosine@(pi * z)) = absolute-value@(e ^ (pi * z) + e ^ (- pi * z)) / 2 >= absolute-value@(absolute-value@(e ^ (pi * z)) - absolute-value@(e ^ (- pi * z))) / 2 = absolute-value@(e ^ (R * pi) - e ^ (- R * pi)) / 2 = (e ^ (R * pi) - e ^ (- R * pi)) / 2
absolute-value@(e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * z * xi)) = e ^ (2 * pi * y * xi) = e ^ (4 * pi * xi)

absolute-value@(((integral _ (- R)) ^ ((- R) + 2 * i))@(f * z * differential-d@(z))) less= ((integral _ (- R)) ^ ((- R) + 2 * i))@(absolute-value@(f * z) * differential-d@(z)) less= 2 cdot e ^ (4 * pi * xi) cdot (2 / (e ^ (R * pi) - e ^ (- R * pi))) = e ^ (4 * pi * xi) / (e ^ (R * pi) - e ^ (- R * pi))
absolute-value@(((integral _ R) ^ (R + 2 * i))@(f * z * differential-d@(z))) less= e ^ (4 * pi * xi) / (e ^ (R * pi) - e ^ (- R * pi))

para.p:
As
→ R ∞
, each of these tends to
0
. Therefore,

Math.text: ((integral _ (- infinity)) ^ infinity)@(f * z * differential-d@(z)) + ((integral _ (infinity + 2 * i)) ^ ((- infinity) + 2 * i))@(f * z * differential-d@(z)) = 2 * pi * i * (e ^ (pi * xi) / (pi * i) + e ^ (3 * pi * xi) / (- pi * i)) = - 2 * e ^ (2 * pi * xi) * (e ^ (pi * xi) - e ^ (- pi * xi))

((integral _ (- infinity)) ^ infinity)@(f * z * differential-d@(z)) = ((integral _ ((- infinity) + 2 * i)) ^ (infinity + 2 * i))@(f * z * differential-d@(z)) - 2 * e ^ (2 * pi * xi) * (e ^ (pi * xi) - e ^ (- pi * xi))

((integral _ ((- R) + 2 * i)) ^ (R + 2 * i))@(f * z * differential-d@(z)) = ((integral _ (- R)) ^ R)@((e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * (x + 2 * i) * xi) / hyperbolic-cosine@(pi * x + 2 * pi * i)) * differential-d@(x))
((integral _ ((- R) + 2 * i)) ^ (R + 2 * i))@(f * z * differential-d@(z))
absent = ((integral _ (- R)) ^ R)@((e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * (x + 2 * i) * xi) / hyperbolic-cosine@(pi * x + 2 * pi * i)) * differential-d@(x))

absent = ((integral _ (- R)) ^ R)@(((e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * x * xi) * e ^ (4 * pi * xi)) / (hyperbolic-cosine@(pi * x) * hyperbolic-cosine@(2 * pi * i) + hyperbolic-sine@(pi * x) * hyperbolic-sine@(2 * pi * i))) * differential-d@(x))

absent = ((integral _ (- R)) ^ R)@(((e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * x * xi) * e ^ (4 * pi * xi)) / (hyperbolic-cosine@(pi * x) * hyperbolic-cosine@(2 * pi * i) + hyperbolic-sine@(pi * x) * hyperbolic-sine@(2 * pi * i))) * differential-d@(x))
absent = e ^ (4 * pi * xi) * ((integral _ (- R)) ^ R)@((e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * x * xi) / hyperbolic-cosine@(pi * x)) * differential-d@(x))
absent = e ^ (4 * pi * xi) * ((integral _ (- R)) ^ R)@((e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * x * xi) / hyperbolic-cosine@(pi * x)) * differential-d@(x))
absent = e ^ (4 * pi * xi) * ((integral _ (- R)) ^ R)@(f * x * differential-d@(x))
absent = e ^ (4 * pi * xi) * ((integral _ (- R)) ^ R)@(f * x * differential-d@(x))
I = ((integral _ (- infinity)) ^ infinity)@(f * z * differential-d@(z))
I = e ^ (4 * pi * xi) * I - 2 * e ^ (2 * pi * xi) * (e ^ (pi * xi) - e ^ (- pi * xi))

I = - 2 * e ^ (2 * pi * xi) * ((e ^ (pi * xi) - e ^ (- pi * xi)) / (1 - e ^ (4 * pi * xi))) = 2 * ((e ^ (pi * xi) - e ^ (- pi * xi)) / (e ^ (2 * pi * xi) - e ^ (- 2 * pi * xi))) = 2 * ((e ^ (pi * xi) - e ^ (- pi * xi)) / ((e ^ (pi * xi) - e ^ (- pi * xi)) * (e ^ (pi * xi) + e ^ (- pi * xi)))) = sech * pi * xi

para.p: which is what we wanted to show. ∎

Math.text: formulae@(((integral _ (- infinity)) ^ infinity)@(e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * xi * x) * e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * a * x) * sech * ((pi * x) / t) * differential-d@(x)) = t * sech * pi * (xi + a) * t, xi element-of R)

((integral _ (- infinity)) ^ infinity)@(e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * x * xi) * e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * a * x) * sech * ((pi * x) / t) * differential-d@(x)) = ((integral _ (- infinity)) ^ infinity)@(e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * (xi + a) * x) * sech * ((pi * x) / t) * differential-d@(x))
((integral _ (- infinity)) ^ infinity)@(e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * x * xi) * e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * a * x) * sech * ((pi * x) / t) * differential-d@(x))
absent = ((integral _ (- infinity)) ^ infinity)@(e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * (xi + a) * x) * sech * ((pi * x) / t) * differential-d@(x))
absent = t * ((integral _ (- infinity)) ^ infinity)@(e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * (xi + a) * t * x) * sech * pi * x * differential-d@(x))
absent = t * ((integral _ (- infinity)) ^ infinity)@(e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * (xi + a) * t * x) * sech * pi * x * differential-d@(x))
absent = t * sech * pi * (xi + a) * t
absent = t * sech * pi * (xi + a) * t
C * tau = (i / tau) * C * (- 1 / tau)

para.p:
For
∈ f
⁢
L 1
( R )
, we define

^ f

by

Math.text: formulae@(widehat@(f) * xi = (integral _ R)@(e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * xi * x) * f * x * differential-d@(x)), xi element-of R)

para.p:
Following Stein and Shakarchi, for
> a 0
, define
F a
to be the set of those functions
f
defined on some neighborhood of
R
in
C
such that
f
is holomorphic on the set
{
∈ z C
:
<
|
⁢ Im z
|
a
}
and for which there is some
> A 0
such that

Math.text: formulae@(absolute-value@(f * (x + i * y)) less= A / (1 + x ^ 2), formulae@(x element-of R, absolute-value@(y) less a))

para.p:
and we set
= F
⋃
> a 0
F a
. The Poisson summation formula 2 footnote 2 2 footnote 2 Elias M. Stein and Rami Shakarchi, Complex Analysis, p. 118, Theorem 2.4. states that for
∈ f F
,

Math.text: (sum _ (n element-of Z))@(f * n) = (sum _ (n element-of Z))@(widehat@(f) * n)

para.p:
For
= z
+ x
⁢ i y
with
<
| y |
1 2
,

Math.text: absolute-value@(sech * ((pi * z) / t)) = 2 / absolute-value@(e ^ (pi * (x + i * y)) - e ^ (- pi * (x + i * y)))
absolute-value@(sech * ((pi * z) / t))
absent = 2 / absolute-value@(e ^ (pi * (x + i * y)) - e ^ (- pi * (x + i * y)))
absent less= 2 / absolute-value@(absolute-value@(e ^ (pi * (x + i * y))) - absolute-value@(e ^ (- pi * (x + i * y))))
absent less= 2 / absolute-value@(absolute-value@(e ^ (pi * (x + i * y))) - absolute-value@(e ^ (- pi * (x + i * y))))
absent = 2 / absolute-value@(e ^ (pi * x) - e ^ (- pi * x))
absent = 2 / absolute-value@(e ^ (pi * x) - e ^ (- pi * x))
absent = sech * pi * absolute-value@(x)
absent = sech * pi * absolute-value@(x)

para.p:
Let
> t 0
. Because the zeros of
cosh
⁢ π z
are
+
⁢ n i
i 2
,
∈ n Z

=
⁢ f
( z )
⁢ sech
⁢ π z
t
belongs to
F
t 2
. Corollary with
= a 0
gives us

Math.text: widehat@(f) * xi = t * sech * pi * xi * t

para.p: so applying the Poisson summation formula we get

Math.text: (sum _ (n element-of Z))@(sech * ((pi * n) / t)) = t * (sum _ (n element-of Z))@(sech * pi * n * t)
(sum _ (n element-of Z))@(secant@((pi * i * n) / t)) = t * (sum _ (n element-of Z))@(secant@(pi * i * n * t))
C * (i / t) = t * C * i * t

para.p:
For
= τ
⁢ i t
this reads

Math.text: C * tau = (i / tau) * C * (- 1 / tau)

para.p:
But
↦ τ
⁢ C
( τ )
and
↦ τ
⁢
i τ
C
(
-
1 τ
)
are holomorphic on
H
, so by analytic continuation this identity is true for all
∈ τ H
. ∎

Math.text: formulae@(C * (1 - 1 / tau) similar-to ((4 * tau) / i) * e ^ ((pi * i * tau) / 2), Im * tau to + infinity)

para.p:
Let
> t 0
and define
=
⁢ f
( z )
⁢
e
-
⁢ π i z
sech
⁢ π z
t
, which we check belongs to
F
t 2
. Corollary with
= a
1 2
tells us that for
> t 0
,

Math.text: formulae@(widehat@(f) * xi = ((integral _ (- infinity)) ^ infinity)@(e ^ (- 2 * pi * i * xi * x) * e ^ (- pi * i * x) * sech * ((pi * x) / t) * differential-d@(x)) = t * sech * pi * (xi + 1 / 2) * t, xi element-of R)

para.p:
Thus the Poisson summation formula gives, as
=
(
- 1
)
n
e
-
⁢ i π n
,

Math.text: (sum _ (n element-of Z))@((- 1) ^ n * sech * ((pi * n) / t)) = t * (sum _ (n element-of Z))@(sech * pi * (n + 1 / 2) * t)
(sum _ (n element-of Z))@((- 1) ^ n * secant@((pi * i * n) / t)) = t * (sum _ (n element-of Z))@(secant@(pi * i * (n + 1 / 2) * t))

para.p:
For
= τ
⁢ i t
this reads

Math.text: (sum _ (n element-of Z))@((- 1) ^ n * secant@((pi * n) / tau)) = (tau / i) * (sum _ (n element-of Z))@(secant@(pi * (n + 1 / 2) * tau))
secant@(pi * n * (1 - 1 / tau)) = 1 / (cosine@(pi * n) * cosine@((- pi * n) / tau) - sine@(pi * n) * sine@((- pi * n) / tau)) = (- 1) ^ n * secant@((pi * n) / tau)

para.p:
so the above states that for
= τ
⁢ i t
,
> t 0
,

Math.text: C * (1 - 1 / tau) = (tau / i) * (sum _ (n element-of Z))@(secant@(pi * (n + 1 / 2) * tau))

para.p:
We assert that both sides of () are holomorphic on
H
, and thus by analytic continuation that () is true for all
∈ τ H
.

Write
= τ
+ σ
⁢ i t
. For
> ν 0
,

Math.text: secant@(pi * nu * tau) = 2 / (e ^ (i * pi * nu * tau) + e ^ (- i * pi * nu * tau)) = 2 / (e ^ (- i * pi * nu * tau) * (e ^ (2 * pi * i * nu * tau) + 1)) = 2 * e ^ (i * pi * nu * tau) * (1 + O * absolute-value@(e ^ (2 * pi * i * nu * tau)))
secant@(pi * nu * tau) = 2 * e ^ (i * pi * nu * tau) + O * absolute-value@(e ^ (3 * pi * i * nu * tau))
absolute-value@(e ^ ((3 * pi * i * tau) / 2)) = e ^ ((- 3 * pi * t) / 2)
secant@(pi * nu * tau) = 2 * e ^ (i * pi * nu * tau) + O * e ^ ((- 3 * pi * t) / 2)
secant@(pi * nu * tau) = secant@(- pi * nu * tau) = 2 * e ^ (- i * pi * nu * tau) + O * e ^ ((- 3 * pi * t) / 2)
secant@(pi * nu * tau) = 2 * e ^ ((i * pi * tau) / 2) + O * e ^ ((- 3 * pi * t) / 2)
secant@(pi * nu * tau) = 2 * e ^ ((i * pi * tau) / 2) + O * e ^ ((- 3 * pi * t) / 2)

(sum _ (n element-of Z))@(secant@(pi * (n + 1 / 2) * tau)) = 2 * e ^ ((i * pi * tau) / 2) + 2 * e ^ ((i * pi * tau) / 2) + O * e ^ ((- 3 * pi * t) / 2) = 4 * e ^ ((i * pi * tau) / 2) + O * e ^ ((- 3 * pi * t) / 2)
formulae@(C * (1 - 1 / tau) = ((4 * tau) / i) * e ^ ((i * pi * tau) / 2) + O * absolute-value@(tau) * e ^ ((- 3 * pi * t) / 2), tau = sigma + i * t)
formulae@(theta * tau = (sum _ (n element-of Z))@(e ^ (pi * i * n ^ 2 * tau)), tau element-of H)

para.p:
By proving that
C
θ 2
is a modular form of weight
0
, it follows that it is constant, and one thus finds that
= C
θ 2
. 3 footnote 3 3 footnote 3 Elias M. Stein and Rami Shakarchi, Complex Analysis, p. 304. One reason that
θ
is significant is that, for
= q
e
⁢ i π τ
,

Math.text: theta * tau ^ 2 = (sum _ (n _ 1 element-of Z))@(q ^ (n _ 1) ^ 2) * (sum _ (n _ 2 element-of Z))@(q ^ (n _ 2) ^ 2)
theta * tau ^ 2
absent = (sum _ (n _ 1 element-of Z))@(q ^ (n _ 1) ^ 2) * (sum _ (n _ 2 element-of Z))@(q ^ (n _ 2) ^ 2)
absent = (sum _ (open-interval@(n _ 1, n _ 2) element-of Z * Z))@(q ^ ((n _ 1) ^ 2 + (n _ 2) ^ 2))
absent = (sum _ (open-interval@(n _ 1, n _ 2) element-of Z * Z))@(q ^ ((n _ 1) ^ 2 + (n _ 2) ^ 2))
absent = ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(r _ 2 * n * q ^ n)
absent = ((sum _ (n = 0)) ^ infinity)@(r _ 2 * n * q ^ n)

para.p:
where
⁢
r 2
( n )
denotes the number of ways that
n
can be expressed as a sum of two squares. We can write
⁢ C
( τ )
as

Math.text: C * tau = 2 * ((sum _ (n = - infinity)) ^ infinity)@(1 / (q ^ n + q ^ (- n)))
C * tau
absent = 2 * ((sum _ (n = - infinity)) ^ infinity)@(1 / (q ^ n + q ^ (- n)))
absent = 2 * ((sum _ (n = - infinity)) ^ infinity)@(q ^ n / (1 + q ^ (2 * n)))
absent = 2 * ((sum _ (n = - infinity)) ^ infinity)@(q ^ n / (1 + q ^ (2 * n)))
absent = 1 + 4 * ((sum _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(q ^ n / (1 + q ^ (2 * n)))
absent = 1 + 4 * ((sum _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(q ^ n / (1 + q ^ (2 * n)))

para.p:
Therefore the identity
=
⁢ θ
( τ )
2
⁢ C
( τ )
can be written as

Math.text: ((sum _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(q ^ n / (1 - q ^ (4 * n))) = ((sum _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(q ^ n * ((sum _ (m = 0)) ^ infinity)@(q ^ (4 * n) ^ m)) = ((sum _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((sum _ (m = 0)) ^ infinity)@(q ^ (n * (4 * m + 1)))) = ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ infinity)@(a * k * q ^ k)

para.p:
where
⁢ a
( k )
denotes the number of divisors of
k
of the form
+
⁢ 4 m
1
, and

Math.text: ((sum _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(q ^ (3 * n) / (1 - q ^ (4 * n))) = ((sum _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(q ^ (3 * n) * ((sum _ (m = 0)) ^ infinity)@(q ^ (4 * n) ^ m)) = ((sum _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((sum _ (m = 0)) ^ infinity)@(q ^ (n * (4 * m + 3)))) = ((sum _ (k = 1)) ^ infinity)@(b * k * q ^ k)

para.p:
where
⁢ b
( k )
denotes the number of divisors of
k
of the form
+
⁢ 4 m
3
. Thus for
≥ n 1
,
